# zsh
# Covert an fps: 60 codec: h264 resolution: 4320x2160 mp4 to HEVC (H.265) for VR180 on OSX using ffmpeg
# - Since hardware acceleration with 'VideoToolbox' on M1, is not optimized for quality, but for speed and efficiency.
# - Add -movflags +faststart to place metadata at start of file for faster playback starting.
# -Consider enabling multi-threading with the -threads option if your system has multiple CPU cores. This will speed up encoding significantly. For example: -threads 8
# - Using the lanczos scaling algorithm is great quality, but bilinear is faster for the GPU to process if speed is a concern.
# canceled -vf "scale=3024:1512:flags=lanczos" `

# # Windows Powershell
$mediaPath = {clipboard}
$mediaName = $mediaPath -replace "\.[^.]*$",""
ffmpeg -i "$mediaName.mp4" `
    -c:v libx265 -crf 21 -preset medium `
    -c:a aac `
    -b:a 128k `
    -pix_fmt yuv420p10le `
    -metadata "stereo_mode=left_right"  `
    -movflags +faststart `
    "$mediaName-HEVC.mp4"


# Mac Terminal
# replce the file extension with nothing and set it to a variable 'mediaName'
# '-sseof -60': before the input file, seek to the last 60 seconds of the video
# -t -60 
# trim the last 60 seconds of video
# -vf "scale=2560:1280:flags=lanczos" `
# copy follow
mediaName="{clipboard}"
mediaName="${mediaName%.*}"
ffmpeg -i "$mediaName.mp4" \
    -c:v libx265 -crf 21 -preset medium \
    -c:a aac -b:a 128k \
    -pix_fmt yuv420p10le \
    -metadata "stereo_mode=left_right" \
    -movflags +faststart \
    "$mediaName-HEVC-VR.mp4"
alfredsnippet.name: Covert HEVC for 180
